title: 109_hr1862
content:
The "Drug Free Sports Act" requires mandatory drug testing for athletes in professional sports associations such as Major League Baseball, the National Basketball Association, the National Football League, and others as determined by the Secretary of Commerce. The "Drug Free Sports Act" mandates drug testing for athletes in professional sports associations within 270 days of enactment. Testing must be random, at least once a year, without prior notification, for performance-enhancing substances specified by the Secretary. The "Drug Free Sports Act" requires random drug testing of athletes participating in professional sports associations throughout the year without prior notification. The Secretary will determine the prohibited substances for testing, which must be conducted by an independent party. Penalties will be imposed for violations. The "Drug Free Sports Act" mandates random drug testing of athletes in professional sports associations by an independent party. Positive tests result in a minimum 2-year suspension, with permanent suspension for repeat offenders. Athletes testing positive for drugs face suspension from professional sports for a minimum of 2 years, with permanent suspension for repeat offenders. Suspensions include loss of pay and the athlete's name is disclosed to the public. Athletes have the right to appeal and a hearing process. Athletes who test positive for drugs face suspension from professional sports, with penalties including loss of pay and public disclosure of the positive test result. An appeals process allows athletes to appeal within 5 days and have a hearing within 30 days, with penalties stayed pending the appeal process. SEC. 4. EXEMPTIONS.

The Secretary may exempt professional sports associations with existing policies exceeding regulations from compliance.

SEC. 5. NONCOMPLIANCE.

Starting 1 year after final rules are issued, the Secretary can fine associations not following regulations, with an initial fine of $5,000,000 and daily increases for noncompliance.

SEC. 6. REPORTS. The Secretary must report on the effectiveness of regulations every 2 years to Congress. Additionally, a study will be conducted on the use of performance-enhancing substances by college and secondary school athletes. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the use of performance-enhancing substances by college and secondary school athletes, assessing testing policies and procedures. A report will be transmitted to relevant committees within 1 year of the Act's enactment. The Comptroller General will assess testing policies for detecting performance-enhancing substances in college and secondary school athletes. A report with recommendations to Congress will be sent to relevant committees within 1 year of the Act's enactment.
